Su deseo mas grande es seguir creciendo en su negocio y ver profesionales a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Ascencia C. P. is a member of the Communal Bank "Women Working for Development ," of the Cabanilla district, in the Lampa province, department of Puno. She is 50 years old, married, and has 7 children. Her education is incomplete, having only completed first grade. She’s been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for only a few years. Her business is a bakery, where she sells loaves of bread. She is requesting a new loan of 500 soles ($175), and she plans to pay it in 6 installments. With this loan she will be able to acquire supplies and materials to continue baking loaves of bread to distribute to the stores in her zone. Her greatest desire is to keep expanding her business and to see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies for her bakery.

loans.name: Mehrichon

texts.ru: Торговля в семье Мехрихон традиционный вид занятия. Ее старшая дочь тоже занимается торговлей и содержит свою семью, а сама Мехрихон несмотря на свои 55 лет тоже торгует тканями. За товаром она ездит в Худжанд на китайский оптовый рынок. Торговля занимает основную часть времени Мехрихон, но что поделаешь раз это основной доход семьи. Мехрихон подала заявку на КИВА и собирается приобрести новый ассортимент тканей.
texts.en:
Sales are a traditional occupation for Mehrichon’s family. Her older daughter also sells products and supports her family and Mehrichon herself despite her 55 years also sell fabrics. She travels to Khujand to the Chinese wholesale market to purchase her products. The sales business takes up the majority of Mehrichon’s time, but what can she do since it is the main source of income for her family. Mehrichon applied to KIVA and plans to acquire a new assortment of fabric.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase fabric assortment

loans.name: Veronica

texts.es:
La señora Veronica es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajando por el Desarrollo”, del distrito Cabanilla, Provincia de Lampa, en el departamento de Puno; ella tiene 30 años de edad, ella tiene de un hijo, es madre soltera, estudio secundaria completa.

La señora Veronica viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 3 años, se dedica venta de abarrotes, ella solicito su primer préstamo de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, dinero que lo invirtió en comprar productos para su tienda, negocio que le va bien.

Ahora viene solicitando un nuevo préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, este dinero piensa invertirlo en capital y comprar lo que necesita para llenar su tienda y refirió que pagará en 06 cómodas cuotas.
texts.en:
Veronica M. A. is a member of the Communal Bank "Women Working for Development," of the Cabanilla district, in the Lampa province, department of Puno. She is 30 years old and is the single mother of a son. She completed secondary school. Veronica has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for 3 years. She sells groceries. Her first loan was for 500 soles and she invested it in buying products for her store. Her business is doing well. She is now requesting a new loan of 500 soles ($175). She will use this money to purchase additional merchandise to stock her store. She plans to repay the loan in 6 installments.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Yobana

texts.es:
La señora Yovana es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres trabajando por el desarrollo“, el distrito de Cabanilla, de la provincia de Lampa, departamento de Puno, ella tiene 24 años de edad, es conviviente, y tiene 01 hijo, ella posee estudios de superior completa (secretariado). 

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace pocos años, ella posee un negocio de radio comunicaciones y giros a distancia, ella desea prestarse préstamo de S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que se comprometa pagar en 06 cuotas. Con dicho préstamo ella desea adquirir algunos materiales para su tienda, ya que también viene iniciando un negocio de venta de productos, su deseo es tener una tienda mucho mas grande.
texts.en:
Yobana C. Apana is a member of the Communal Bank "Women Working for Development ," of the Cabanilla district, in the Lampa province, department of Puno. She is 24 years old, in a common law marriage, and has a son. She completed secondary school. She’s worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for only a few years. She owns a radio communications business and she is requesting a loan of 500 soles ($175). She is committed to repaying the loan in 6 installments. With the loan she will acquire some materials for her store because she is also initiating the sale of products and her desire is to have a much larger store.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase products for her store.

loans.name: 39-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en: Thường

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Ricky

texts.en:
Ricky  A. is a 38 year old man from Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City , Philippines. Ricky is married and lives with his 4 children. He is involved into simple traditional gold mining. Ricky wakes up early and starts his daily activity which is called " pamiling". This is the traditional way of gold mining. It uses only simple tools to look for gold along the river. At the end of the day they deliver their gold to their buyer and receive a maximum payment of PHP 200.00 per day. 

Eventually, Ricky decided to buy and sell his own gold. He required capital to start up this business and asked for support from HSPFI ( Kiva Partner) and immediately went into business. Ricky is now engaged in the buying and selling of gold. He is buying gold from the traditional miners and sells it in the city. Ricky is one of the active members of HSPFI. According to him, HSPFI greatly assisted him. This time, Ricky is soliciting his 3rd cycle loan amounting to PHP 11,000.00. This is intended for  improving his business.  He wants to buy all the gold from the traditional miners at their mine fields. In addition, he wants to purchase more equipment that will be used in the gold buying activity.He aims to earn a bigger income and someday wants to invest in a jewelry shop or a pawnshop on the mine fields.

loans.use: To purchase addtional apparatus to use for gold buying

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ianesi

texts.en: Ianesi S., 33, is married with two children.  She has one year of experience in the German Buns business. She sells to the villagers five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 320 Tala.  SPBD loans are Ianesi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, frying pan, coconuts

loans.name: Senia

texts.en: Senia T., 30, is married with three children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public six days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala. SPBD loans are Senia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, pesticides, fertilizer, a plant sprayer and vegetable seeds

loans.name: Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani

texts.en:
Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani (DNR.M-0639) is a 45 year old woman living in the town of Dsn. Pangkung Buluh, Ds. Kaliakah. She is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income from the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 300,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000,000 IDR from DINARI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from DINARI. Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children.

About DINARI:

The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani - (DNR.M-0639) merupakan 45 tahun pria. Dia (laki-laki) tinggal di kota Dsn. Pangkung Buluh, Ds. Kaliakah. Dia (laki-laki) menikah dan memiliki 2 anak usia sekolah. Untuk membiayai hidup, Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani memiliki & menjalankan usaha. Bisnis beroperasi di sektor pertanian. Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah memelihara ternak. Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 5 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani menghasilkan sekitar 300,000 IDR sebulan.

Dalam 2008, Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani bergabung DINARI untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari DINARI. Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Dia (laki-laki) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 5,000,000 IDR. Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari DINARI. Ni Kadek Ayu Ardani berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis untuk membayar biaya sekolah anak-anak peminjam.

Tentang DINARI:

Misi DINARI adalah memperjuangkan kelestarian lingkungan, memberdayakan kaum miskin, dan menyediakan kesempatan pembangunan sosial ekonomi bagi pemilik usaha kecil.

*Catatan: Untuk memaksimalkan efisiensi & menurunkan biaya, pinjaman ini ditempelkan menggunakan templat sehingga dapat diterjemahkan otomatis oleh Kiva. . Mengingat bahwa terjemahan manual atas profil memakan biaya besar, Kiva menciptakan templat ini untuk Mitra Lapangan untuk memungkinkan mereka terus menempelkan pinjaman dalam Bahasa sambil memberikan informasi yang bermutu & akurat kepada para pemberi pinjaman Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en: Juvy M. is 34 years old.  He is married and  a responsible father  to his 3 children. His wife helps him  in raising their family. They live in Tuburan , Cagayan de Oro City, Philippines. Juvy is engaged in buying and selling  of fruits. He has a stall in their village where he displays and sells his product. Juvy's business is indeed doing well. Most of his customers are from  their Barangay District and nearby places. He would like to uplift the status of his business. Through the support of HSPFI gave to Juvy (Kiva Partner), its not possible for him to accomplish what he is aiming  for his business. Juvy is now applying for a loan amounting to PHP 11,000.00.  The said amount will be a great help to him. He could purchase additional stocks of fruits for additional inventory and he would be able to save for the needs of his family. Juvy is hoping for the assistance that the organization would extend to him.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of fruits for resale

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tagisia

texts.en: Tagisia T., 48, is married with 2 children.  She has many years of experience in the vegetable growing business. She sells to the general public 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Tagisia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase farming supplies

loans.name: Faatupu

texts.en: Faatupu M., 39, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the general public 6 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 260 Tala (~108 USD).  SPBD loans are Faatupu’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine and materials

loans.name: Etevise

texts.en: Etevise S., 61, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 360 Tala (~150 USD).  SPBD loans are Etevise’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and farm implements

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina P., 24, is married with 2 children.  She has 2 years of experience with a general store. She sells to the public 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Tina’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Ni Luh Sarini

texts.en:
Ni Luh Sarini is a 40 year-old woman living in the town of Dsn. Pangkung Buluh, in Kaliakah.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ni Luh Sarini owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling of home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling kitchen supplies & products to tourists and local community members.  Ni Luh Sarini has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 900,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ni Luh Sarini joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ni Luh Sarini has successfully repaid a previous loan of 450,000 IDR from DINARI.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.Ni Luh Sarini is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 IDR which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by this borrower from DINARI. Ni Luh Sarini plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About DINARI:
The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Norma Rae

texts.en: Norma Rae A., 38, is married with 7 children.  She has one year of experience in the restaurant business. She serves the public 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Norma Rae’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and furnishings

loans.name: Qandia Gul Group

texts.en: Qandia Gul is the group leader of Qandia Gul group. There are two members of this group that would like to expand their businesses and want to take a loan of 20000 Afghani for a term of 8 months. Qandia Gul wants to take a loan for her bakery. Salema wants to take a loan for her brother who has a general store. Salema's brother wants to expand his business and attract more clients. They are very happy for this process of obtaining a loan in Afghanistan because every poor worker can use it and can change their businesses and their lives. They want to thank lenders around the world.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en: Jacinta S., 30 and married with six children, has many years of experience in the popcorn business. She sells to the general public three days per week and has a weekly net cash flow of about 150 Tala ($62).  She has no previous loans with SPBD which is her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase corn and cooking oil.

loans.name: Laulaau

texts.en: Laulaau L. L. is 57 years old and married with seven children. She sells biscuits seven days per week, and has many years of experience in this line of business. She has no previous loans with Kiva partner, SPBD. Laulaau expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 WST. SPBD loans are Laulaau’s only access to capital because she has never qualified for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, yeast and coconuts

loans.name: Palema Kalifa

texts.en: Palema Kalifa A., 36, is married with six children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business, and sells to the public five days per week. Palema Kalifa has no previous loans with Kiva partner, SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 WST. SPBD loans are Palema Kalifa’s only access to capital because she has never qualified for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase weedkiller, chemicals, knives and a wheelbarrow

loans.name: Laufofoga

texts.en: Laufofoga P., 35, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in the iced cake business, and sells to her fellow villagers seven days per week. She has no previous loans with Kiva partner, SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 WST. SPBD loans are Laufofoga’s only access to capital because she has never qualified for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer, cordial, sugar and foam cups

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sari

texts.en:
Ni Ketut Sari is a 55 year-old woman living in the town of Dsn. Pangkung Buluh, in Kaliakah.  She is married and has 3 adult -aged children.  To make a living, Ni Ketut Sari owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  Ni Ketut Sari has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 500,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ni Ketut Sari joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ni Ketut Sari has successfully repaid a previous loan of 300,000 IDR from DINARI.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ni Ketut Sari is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 IDR which will be used to invest in renovating the business. The loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from DINARI. Ni Ketut Sari plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About DINARI:
The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in renovating the business

loans.name: Aitu

texts.en: Aitu P., 36, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the banana plantation business. She sells to the general public 6 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (about US $231).  SPBD loans are Aitu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Farming supplies

loans.name: Solopeta

texts.en: Solopeta F., 42, is married with 6 children. She has many years of experience in the lawn mowing business. She sells to the general public 5 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD). SPBD loans are Solopeta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for loans at the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase a new mower and labour cost for maintenance of old mowers

loans.name: Bagam Nash Group

texts.en:
Bagam Nash is the group leader. There are three members in this group. They all want to better their businesses.

Bagam Nash wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store. Bagam Nash's husband wants to expand his business and to attract more clients. Amanullah wants to take a loan for a new machine for his car. Shbnam wants to take a loan for a new machine for her tailoring business. They are thankful for AFS and Kiva.

loans.use: To expand a general store

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma M., 38 years old, is married and blessed with three children. She lives in Purok 5A, Neopoda, Tambo, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte in Southern Philippines. Her husband works as a hollow block maker. She helps her husband through fish selling in their neighbor and nearby villages.

She was happy to hear that HSPFI is willing to extend financial assistance to aspiring entrepreneurs like her. She wants to access a HSPFI micro-finance loan in the amount of PHP 4,000 to have additional capital for her business.

loans.use: the purchase of fish, shrimps, sea weed, and squids

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida C., 55, is still able and willing to help her husband provide for the family. She sells different items in their township and in neighboring villages. She purchases items that are in demand in the market and as soon as she runs out of stock, she repurchases the same items or other salable items.Her husband is a regular employee of NGCP as a driver and mechanic. For her first loan she wants to access the amount of PHP 4,000 to purchase umbrellas, chlorine, and dried fish.

loans.use: the purchase of umbrellas, dried fish, chlorine

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine O., 29, is a mother of 3 children. She has one elementary student and 5- and 3-year-old kids. Her husband works as an on-call carpenter. With their present situation, Aida financially helps her husband through peddling homemade food such as longganisa (sausage), hot dogs and lumpia (spring rolls). She strives to prepare financial support for the schooling of all her children. For her first loan, she wants to apply for the amount of PHP 4,000 to HSPFI's  partner, KIVA.

loans.use: purchase longganisa (Philippine sausage) and hot dogs for re-sale

location.town: Tambo, Hinaplanon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma has been a chicken seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She belongs to the Uadilifu group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. She works at her business for 8 hours daily.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more chickens for sale, to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Mwajuma is 35 years old, married, and has five children: ages 19, 17, 14, 12 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for sale, to improve her business.

loans.name: Fadhilat Group

texts.en:
Jabu has been a bread seller and owned a small restaurant in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 10 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $135. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to add to her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Jabu is married, and has five children: ages 19, 17, 14, 12 and 2. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwanahamis and MwaJ.. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more itmes to add her current stock.

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn V. is 37 years old . She's married and happily raising her 6 children. Her husband went into farming to sustain the needs of the family. Arlyn think that farming will not always serve their needs so she decided to put up a mini grocery business. From this, she earns extra money that will somehow replenish their everyday needs.

Arlyn's mini grocery store sells staple goods. This helps a lot of people around them for they can directly access their needs. Arlyn needs to have more stock in her mini grocery for her to accommodate all the demands of her customers.

Arlyn is a current member of HSPFI (a Kiva Partner). She wants to express her gratitude to the organization that supported her business. Without hesitation, Arlyn now is applying for loan amounting to PHP 11,000. This is intended for buying goods and other items needed for the mini grocery store.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her mini grocery store

location.town: Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Amire Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Amire M. is the group leader. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to use the money for their businesses.

Amier M. wants to take a loan to expand his fresh fruit business. Fatana wants to take a loan for her husband’s embroidery business. He wants to buy necessary materials for his shop. Manezha wants to take a loan for a new machine for her tailoring business. And M. Amier wants to take a loan for his business. He wants to buy necessary materials for his general store. 

They want to thank Kiva and AFSG for bringing this process of loans to Afghanistan to help poor people.

loans.use: For expanding business

loans.name: Anh's Group

texts.en:
Anh Thị Vân Nguyễn was born in 1984. She has a shop in the market. She lives with her husband and 2 young children. Her family has a monthly income of about 4.000.000 VND (224 USD). She wants to borrow 6.758.000 VND ( or 380 USD ) to buy clothing to re-sell in the market.

There are 4 other Fund participants in her group :,P> Hoạch Thị Nguyễn was born in 1953. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND ( or 380 USD ) to expand her confectionery.

Cúc Thị Nguyễn was born in 1946. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND ( or 380 USD ) to expand her stationery store.

Hoa Thị Nguyễn was born in 1970. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ( or 282 USD ) to to buy pigs and chicken to raise.

Huyền T. Lương was born in 1974. She wants to borrow 654.000 VND ( or 37 USD ) to buy feed for her pig.

loans.use: to buy clothing to re-sell in the market

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki has been a khanga seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She belongs to Hidaya njema group loan (Group code 2021). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $40. Every day, she works at her business for 7 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more khanga and other items for sale, to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Riziki is 28 years old, married, and has two children: ages 6 and 3.

loans.use: To buy more khanga and other items for sale, to improve her business.

loans.name: Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en:
Fadhila is a clothes seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. Every day, she works at her business for 7 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes, to add to her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Fadhila is 35 years old, married, and has seven children: ages 18, 16, 14, 12, 10, 8 and 5. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Maryam and Mwajuma. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Dien's Group

texts.en:
Diện Thị Trần was born in 1972. She and her husband go to work at the market together. She has two daughters. They have a monthly income of about 3.500.000 VND (or about $197). Everybody in her group loves her. She is a group leader. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND (or about $38) to buy goods to resell in the market.

There are three other fund participants in her group. Thúy Thị Trần was born in 1975. She wants to borrow 4.142.000 VND (or about $233) to repair her house. Thái Thị Nguyễn was born in 1982. She wants to borrow 4.578.000 VND (or about $258) to buy a pig and chicken. Mùi Thị Nguyễn was born in 1964. She wants to borrow 5.450.000 VND (or about $307) to buy a pig and chicken.

loans.use: To buy more goods to resell at the market

loans.name: Hafsa

texts.en:
Hafsa  has made a living selling chickens in the Melinne neighborhood of  Zanzibar for the last two years. She is a member of the Tujitahidi loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Hafsa works at her business for seven hours a day. She is applying for her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more chickens to sell. She hopes that his loan will allow her to increase her profits and expand her business.  

Hafsa is 28  years old, married and has two children, ages 4  and 2.

loans.use: To improve her business by buying more chickens to sell

loans.name: Bega Kwa Bega Group

texts.en:
Lela  makes a living selling coconuts and oranges in the Mwera neighborhood of Zanzibar. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155 and works at her business for eight hours a day. She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more oranges and coconuts to sell. She hopes that this loan will allow her to increase her profits and grow her business.  

Lela is married and has two children, ages 12 and 12. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow loan group member, Hidaya, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To improve her business by buying more oranges and coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Pura

texts.en: Pura  L. is 60 years old, married and the mother of six children, all of whom are married. She lives with her family in Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City, Philippines. Her husband is a hard-working farmer who occasionally helps his wife run her banana-selling business. Pura thinks that the money she earns is not enough to meet their needs, and has decided to take out a loan to expand her business and increase her income. She hopes to earn enough money to help pay for expenses like electricity. Pura extends her hearfelt gratitude to the lenders who support her request for more funding.

loans.use: To expand a banana-selling business

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Da's Group

texts.en: Đa Thị Đỗ was born in 1983 and lives with her parents at Kinh No villarge. She supports herself by making and selling clothing, and earns a daily income of about $5. She makes her clothes at home. She leads a loan group that has two other members, Thúy Thị Nguyễn and Hồng Thị Bùi, each of whom want to borrow $224 to breed pigs and poultry.

loans.use: To expand three small businesses

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane D. V. is 30 years old, single and has two children aged five months and two years. She supports her young family by engaging in different types of business endeavors. Currently, she makes a living by designing gowns. She also sells food, a line of work which is currently her main source of income.  After learning that HSPFI offers financial assistance to small businesses such as hers, she immediately grasped the opportunity to acquire more funding. She is applying for her first loan to acquire the money she needs to expand her food-selling businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional food to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Christine Luyombya ‘S Group

texts.en: Christine is fifty-four years old and is married with six children, aged eighteen to thirty-two. She owns a seven- room house where she is staying with eight people. She takes care of her parents. She has access to electricity and piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day. Christine has a retail shop in Kampala city and does her shopping in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in town.  She earns her living by selling at the market.  Christine uses public transport to and from work and rents her business place at $46 a month. She sells to all categories of people and works six days week. Her monthly expenses include rent for the business, food for the family and school fees. She has had this business for five years.  This is her ninth loan since she joined the Kiva partner, MCDT, and has been with MCDT for five years. Christine wants to use this loan to buy more commodities for her shop. She is working toward seeing her business grow bigger and she hopes to own a permanent business location.

loans.use: To buy more commdities for her shop

loans.name: Trần's Group

texts.en:
L. Trần Thị  (20209010004) is a 28-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Băc Ninh.  L. is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 0 (4).


L. is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To make a living, L. is starting a business venture in the food sector operating a butcher shop.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from butchering & selling beef in the local community.  L. has just started operating this business and earns approximately 4.000.000 VND a month from these activities.


L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  L. is requesting a loan from SEDA for the first time.    She is now requesting a new loan of 5.152.000 VND which will be used to invest in renovating the business.  The loan will be the first loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn Thị Thuỷ (20209010001) is a 28 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


2.  Nguyễn Thị N. (20209010002) is a 35 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


3.  Nguyễn Thị P. (20209010003) is a 29 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a restaurant.


4.  Lê Thị

loans.use: To invest in renovating the business

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza V. is 49  years old, divorced, and has two  children: ages 30 and 27. She has been a dressmaker in the Mikunguni neighborhood of  Zanzibar for 15  years.She belongs to the Nyota njema  group. Aziza currently earns an average monthly profit of $105. Each day she works at her business for 8 hours.  


Aziza is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more items to improve her business.

loans.name: Kijakazi

texts.en:
Kijakazi A. is 43 years old, married, and has a 2 year old child. Kijakazi has been a clothes and fish seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of  Zanzibar for 3 years. She belongs to the Nyota njema group.  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $40. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.  

Kijakazi is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and fish  for resale, to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for other uses.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and fish for resale

loans.name: Hafsa

texts.en:
Hafsa J. is 28 years old, married, and has three  children: ages 11, 9  and 2. Hafsa  has owned a small restaurant in the Mikunguni neighborhood of  Zanzibar for 3 years. She belongs to the Uvivu si kazi  group .  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $560. Daily she works at her business for 8 hours.  

Hafsa is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to increase her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future uses.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her current stock.

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  femmes du groupe Jiguisseme (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 31ans, ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent majoritairement dans des  familles monogames à Ouayerma I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de tasses, de fruits, d’articles de boutique et de boubous.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, tous les  prêts passés ont été bien remboursés...
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 2douzaines de tasses, 10 paniers de fruits (oranges, mandarines) et 10 régimes de bananes, 4 colis d’articles de boutique et  5 dizaine de boubous. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Médine à Sikasso ville et  dans   les  localités avoisinantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues la plupart au comptant au marché de Ouayerma, dans des boutiques et souvent dans des familles à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes..
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women of this Jiguisseme group (all married) have an average age of 31 and on average 3 children. They mostly live in monogamous families in Ouayerma I, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.

They have various businesses, among others selling dishes, fruit, boutique items, and boubous (flowing robes worn by men and women). They collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele and are on their third solidarity loan, all the preceding loans having been correctly reimbursed.

With this new loan they expect to buy 2 dozen dishes, 10 baskets of fruit (oranges, mandarines), and 10 stalks of bananas, 4 packages of boutique articles, and 5 dozen boubous. They stock up on merchandise at the Médine market in the town of Sikasso and in the surrounding areas.

The merchandise is sold mostly for cash in the market of Ouayerma, in the shops and often in families, to a clientele composed of men and women.

They each expect to make a monthly average profit of 18,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and the rest will be invested back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita E. is a 52-year-old married mother of three sons who lives in Tobias Fornier, Antique Province. Most locals still call Tobias Fornier "Dao" which was the city's name before it was renamed after a popular local political leader. Amelita's husband Mario is a bus conductor. Her oldest son is 18 and attends college; the other two are in high school.

Amelita plans to use the proceeds of this loan to buy rice, fish, and vegetables such as onion and garlic for resale at market. She has been selling foodstuffs at market for about 10 years, and uses her income to support the educational needs of her sons.

Amelita hopes that all of her sons will grow up to have stable jobs. She would like to live in a more comfortable house, and have a stall at market from which to sell her goods.

loans.use: To buy rice, fish, and vegetables for resale at market.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia S. is a 41-year-old mother of three. Her husband Dante is a tricycle driver. She buys and resells bangus fry (bangus is a local name for milk fish) to help support the family. She started getting loans from ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) in 2002. Her past loans have been used for many things for the house and for the education of her eldest daughter who just graduated with a degree in Hotel and Restaurant Management.

She applied for this loan to finish paying off the old tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) from her previous loan and to make a partial payment on a brand new motorcycle. She hopes that in the future she will be able to save enough money to expand her business and build a better house. She also dreams of sending her other two children to college.

loans.use: To be used to finish paying off the old tricycle and partial payment on the new motorcycle.

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa (toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 24ans ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles monogames à Ouayerma I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, tous les prêts précédents  se sont  bien dénoués. Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de tasses, de glacières, de savons et d’articles de boutique.  
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 3 douzaines de tasses en plastique, 1 dizaine de glacière, 8 cartons de savons et 3 paquets d’ articles de boutique. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Ouayerma, de façon ambulante, dans des boutiques et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne.
Certaines femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa ambitionnent acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The women of the Soro Yiriwa group (all married) have an average age of 24 and on average, 2 children. They live in monogamous families in Ouayerma I, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.

They work with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele and are on their third solidarity loan, both the preceding loans having been reimbursed correctly. They have various businesses, among others selling dishes, coolers, soap and boutique articles.

With this new loan they expect to buy 3 dozen dishes made of plastic, 1 dozen coolers, 8 cases of bars of soap, and 3 packets of boutique articles. They buy their merchandise at the big marketplace in the town of Sikasso. The merchandise is sold at the market in Ouayerma, door-to-door, in the shops and at home, to a clientele composed of men and women, mostly for cash.

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 11,500 F CFA of which part will be used for the needs of the family and the rest put into savings.

The ambition of certain women from the Soro Yiriwa group is to buy a plot of land on which to build a home.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Adiaratou

texts.fr:
Madame  Adiaratou O. est mariée et mère de 4 enfants (2 garçons et 2 filles). Elle est née le 24 Janvier 1974 à Sikasso, 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali.  Elle vit avec son mari et leurs enfants à Kadiolo  dans le quartier Noumousso.
Elle mène son activité de commerce d’articles divers depuis 6 ans (vente de draps, de wax, d’ encens, de jus et de la glace). Expérimentée en raison des années d’activité, elle le fait avec réussite.
Elle est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt précédent a été remboursé sans difficulté. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt un congélateur,  des tissus  et des draps de lit. Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Faso, à Sikasso ville, à Kadiolo et environnants. Elle vend au comptant et à crédit (en gros et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car elle ambitionne acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation à Sikasso ville.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adiaratou O. is married and the mother of 4 children (2 sons and 2 daughters). She was born on January 24, 1974 in Sikasso, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. She lives with her husband and children in Kadiolo in the Noumousso district.

She has had her business selling general merchandise (bedsheets, "wax" brand African print cloth, incense, juice and ice) for 6 years. As she had had a lot of experience, she succeeds very well at this business. She is on her second loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. The preceding loan was reimbursed without difficulty.

With this loan she expects to buy a freezer, some fabric, and bedsheets. She buys her merchandise in Burkino Faso, in the town of Sikasso, and in Kadiolo and its surroundings. She sells for cash or credit (wholesale and retail) to a clientele composed of women and men.

She expects to earn a monthly average profit of 45,000 F CFA of which part will be used to help her husband cover household expenses and the rest will be put into savings since her ambition is to be able to buy a plot of land on which to build a house in the town of Sikasso.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Rahma is a clothes seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Hidaya Njema group loan (Group code 2021). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. Every day she works at her business for 7 hours.

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for sale, to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Rahma is 41 years old, married, and has three children: ages 20, 15 and 13.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale, to improve her business.

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina owns a small hotel in the Mwera neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Umoja ni nguvu group loan. She currently earns very little monthly profit. She works daily at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items, to improve her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Zaina is married and has four children: ages 26, 17, 12 and 6.

loans.use: To buy more food items to improve her business

loans.name: Assétou

texts.fr:
Assétou S. est une veuve qui est mère de 5 enfants (2garçons et 3 filles). Elle est née vers 1980 à Awanou en République de la Côte d’Ivoire, un pays frontalier du Mali.  Elle vit dans la maison de son défunt mari avec ses enfants à Kadiolo quartier Koko.
Elle fait  le commerce  depuis 6 ans  avec la vente de pagnes real.  Elle vend également de temps à autres les petits articles de son jeune frère qui est commerçant..
 Elle est à son troisième prêt individuel avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Les prêts passés  se sont  bien dénoués
Elle compte acheter, une vingtaine de pièces de pagnes real. Elle  s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Elle vend au comptant et à crédit (en gros et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes et très  souvent aux associations féminines.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 60.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les dépenses familiales et l’autre partie sera investie dans son commerce
texts.en:
Assétou S. is a widow with 5 children (2 sons and 3 daughters). She was born around 1980 in Awanou in Côte d’Ivoire, a country which borders Mali. She lives in the house of her late husband with her children in Kadiolo district Koko.

She has been in business for 6 years selling "Real" brand "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth). From time to time, she also sells small items for her younger brother who is a merchant. She is on her third individual loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. Both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

She intends to buy 20 or so lengths of "Real" pagne. She does her buying in the big marketplace of the town of Sikasso. She sells for cash or credit (wholesale and retail) to a clientele composed of women and men, and very often to women's groups.

She expects to make a monthly average profit of 60,000 F CFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the rest invested back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "Real" brand "pagnes" for re-sale

loans.name: Foulematou

texts.fr:
Madame  Foulematou Berthé est mariée, mère de 8 enfants (3garçons et 5 filles). Elle est née vers 1969 à Bamako (capitale du Mali) en Afrique de l’Ouest. Elle vit chez son époux dans une famille nucléaire avec leurs enfants à Kadiolo ville dans le quartier Noumousso.
Elle fait l’achat vente des condiments alimentaires (concentrée de tomate, oignons, sel de cuisine, cube maggi, poudre de gombo, l’ail, laurier, poivre,tomates fraiches etc) depuis 10 ans. Expérimentée en raison des années d’activité, elle mène son commerce avec réussite.
Elle est à son troisième prêt individuel avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter,  8 paquets de condiments. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Sikasso ville, de Kadiolo ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elle vend la plupart au comptant (en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes.
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car elle  envisage acheter un congélateur pour diversifier produits
texts.en:
Mrs. Foulematou Berthé is married and the mother of 8 children (3 sons and 5 daughters). She was born around 1969 in Bamako (capital of Mali) in West Africa. She lives with her husband in a nuclear family with their children in the town of Kadiolo, Noumousso district.

She has been buying and selling condiments (tomato paste, onions, cooking salt, Maggi cubes, okra powder, garlic, bay leaves, pepper, fresh tomatoes, etc.) for 10 years. Since she has so many years of experience, she goes about her business with success. She is on her third loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. Both preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

With this new loan, she intends to buy 8 packets of condiments. She buys her merchandise at the market in the town of Sikasso, in the town of Kadiolo, and the surrounding villages. She sells mostly for cash (retail) to a clientele composed mostly of women.

She expects to make a monthly average profit of 25,000 F CFA of which part will be used to bolster her working capital and the rest put into savings since she hopes to buy a freezer so as to diversify the goods she sells.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est constitué de quatre femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 2 enfants. Elles   vivent majoritairement dans des  familles   monogames à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région  administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles l’ont sollicité afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle qui devient de plus en plus grand et exigeant. Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente d’habillements pour enfants,  de savons et d’encens..  
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 50 colis  d’habits pour enfants, 50 cartons de savons, 40 bouteilles de parfums et des graines pour la fabrication de l’encens. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et au Burkina Faso pays frontalier du Mali. 
Les marchandises sont vendues plupart au comptant au grand marché de Sikasso ville  et souvent de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi is composed of four married women who average 35 years of age and two children each. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Médine, a district in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

The group members are on their third solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They requested a loan to satisfy the needs of their customers, who are becoming more and more numerous and demanding. The group members do a diversity of work, including selling children's clothing, soap, and incense. With this loan, they intend to buy fifty packages of children's clothing, fifty boxes of soap, forty bottles of perfume, and some seeds for making incense. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of the city of Sikasso and in Burkina Faso, a country bordering Mali. The merchandise is sold to customers composed of men and women mostly in cash transaction at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and often by going door-to-door.

The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used for family needs, and the other portion will be invested in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Salmina Group

texts.en:
Mwanapili has been a juice seller and the owner of a small charcoal and firewood store in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She belongs to the Salmina group loan (Group code 2019). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood to expand her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Mwanapili is 35 years old, married, and has three children, aged 12, 10, and 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwaka, Fatma and Amina. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar A. is married and has three children who inspire him to work hard.

Omar began a small grocery store with a small amount of capital from his savings. Today his clientele has grown greater and his grocery has become more popular. He is asking for a loan so that he may expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store.

Omar is very grateful to everyone who helps him achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: To expand the variety of goods sold in his store

loans.name: Esther Nakalema‘S Group

texts.en:
Esther is 36 years of age. She is married with four children aged 6 and 13 years, including a set of twins. All her children go to school. She rents a one-room house where she is staying with seven people. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has access to electricity and piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Esther operates a retail shop in Mulago and that is how she earns a living. She doesn’t incur any transport expenses because she lives near her shop. Esther receives about 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people on a retail basis. She works seven days a week. Her monthly expenses include the license for the business premises, rent for her home and business, feeding her family, and school fees.

Esther has been in this business for four years now. This is her first loan ever since she joined MCDT two weeks ago. Esther wants to use this loan to buy more home products for resale. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and also to start a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more home products for her shop

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena R. is a dynamic member of HSPFI (a Kiva partner). She lives in Baluarte, Lumbia Cagayan de Oro City, Philippines. She is married and a responsible mother of her five children. Her husband is a laborer. They help each other so that they could sustain the needs of their children who are primarily dependent on them.

Lucena is engaged in the buying and selling of fruits. At first, she used her own savings for the purchase of fruits (bananas) she intend to sell. Later, she noticed that her business is doing great. She'd like to have more supply to meet the demand of her customers, whom she termed as her "suki," meaning her frequent customers who usually buy her products.

She decided to pledge with HSPFI for the loan opportunity they offered. Then she performed her business with higher income compared to her previous activity. She is very much grateful to the organization who lends support to her business. From that, she gains extra income which she uses to pay her debts and helps support the tuition of her children whom she sends to school. As of this time, Lucena is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000.00 for purchase of additional fruits intended for selling.

loans.use: For procurement of additional fruits intended for selling

location.town: Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tarciana

texts.en:
Tarciana S., a 44-year-old resident of Neopoda, Tambo, Hinaplanon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte in Southern Philippines. She is widow with four children. She engages in food and snack -making. One of her children is married and the three others are in school.

Being a single mom, Tarciana works hard to provide the needs of her children. Every day, she peddles her snacks in their neighborhood and nearby villages. Income is not sufficient to supply the family's daily needs that's why she wants to increase her stocks to generate higher income. To be able to fulfill her plan, she wants to apply a loan from HSPFI (a Kiva partner) amounting to Php 4,000. If granted, this will be a big help for the family. This will be Tarciana's 1st loan with HSPFI.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for snack and food preparation

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 40 years old and she is married with 5 children. She sells provisions and foodstuffs. She hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Gulboy

texts.ru: Аламуродов Гулбой житель города Яван. Он живет вместе со своей семьей очень далеко от центра города.Он женат и имеет шестерых детей.  В его кишлаке занимаются в основном сельским хозяйством . Он имеет участок земли , засеивает его различными видами овощей. Обратился к нам за кредитом и на него планирует купить семена и удобрения. Это поможет ему своевременно засеять земли.
texts.en:
Gulboy A. is a resident of the city of Yavan. He lives with his family very far from the center of the city. He is married and has six children. In his village people mostly work in agriculture. He has a plot of land and plants different varieties of vegetables on it. He has turned to us for credit and plans to use it to purchase seeds and fertilizer. This will help him to sow his land at the right time.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Rami

texts.en:
Rami A. was born in 1974 and has 3 children, He is dedicated to the production of dairy cattle. With a lot of effort and sacrifice, he carries out this work every day for the purpose of improving the conditions of his family and bringing the daily bread to his table.

The need that Rami faces is to invest in the development of his business through the purchase of cows. In this he hopes that Ryada, with the help of Kiva, will offer him the loan to help him to do well, along with his family.

loans.use: purchase more cows

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị Ước Group
loans.use: To invest in renovating the business

loans.name: Mauwa

texts.en:
Mauwa is an orange and coconut seller in the Mwera neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Ega Kwa Bega group loan (Group code 2020). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.

She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more oranges and coconuts for sale, to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Mauwa is 30 years old, married, and has two children: ages 12 and 6. She also cares for one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more oranges and coconuts for sale

loans.name: Sounam Group

texts.en:
Sounam is the group leader of Sounam group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses to purchase more materials and make good incomes for their families in the future.

Frowzan and Sounam want to take a loan for their business of bead working; they want to buy necessary materials for their business. Sayeda wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of stick selling. He wants to buy sticks for his business. Nellofar wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. She wants to buy three new machines for her business. They all want to buy necessary materials for their businesses.

With this loan they can make their businesses grow, support their families, and make a better future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: Supplies for beadwork business

loans.name: Happy

texts.en:
Happy is 38 years old and married with two children. She has a salon where she makes lovely hairstyles for her customers.

She hopes for a loan of N80,000 to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Adore

texts.en:
Adore G. is a 46 year-old member of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap,Inc.), widow, and mother of four. She is a courageous and humble mother, willing to work very hard to support the needs of her family. Her eldest son, Apolinario, is the one helping in her business. For additional income, Adore sometimes does laundry for her neighbors and catches bangus fry. She is saving for the education of her three kids who are in secondary school.

She applied for this loan for one unit of payment for a motorcycle, and to buy materials for the repair of her pump boat such as plywood, lumber, nails, epoxy, and paint. She hopes that through her loan, her son will be able to catch more fish and the motorcycle for hire will be fully paid for from its income. She dreams that in the future, her three daughters will graduate and earn a degree to land a better job.

loans.use: Payment on motorcycle and boat repair materials

loans.name: Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en:
Farida has been a clothes, shoes and perfumes seller in the Milinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She belongs to Mwanzo mgumu group loan (Group code 2018). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She works at her business for eight hours every day.

Farida is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes, perfumes and shoes to add her current stock, to expand her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Farida is 34 years old, married, and has a 12-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Asha, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, shoes, and perfume to add her current stock to expand her business

loans.name: Nesa

texts.en:
Nesa R. supports herself with her small business. She sells RTW (ready-to-wear) items to her neighbors and friends.

Nesa is a widow, 50 years old, and unfortunately doesn't have any children. She is planning to improve her existing business so as to be able to help out her sisters with school expenses and other family finances.

Nesa is now applying for a loan with HSPFI for the amount of PHP 4,000 to realize her plan.

loans.use: To purchase more ready-to-wear items for sale

location.town: Purok 5, Tambo, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Husan

texts.ru: Аламуродов Хусейн житель города Яван. Женат и имеет четверых детей. Возраст 38 лет. Всю жизнь занимается сельским хозяйством. Сеет лук и другие виды овощей. Занимается этим видом бизнеса почти всю жизнь.Дело приносит доход , в случае если он получит хороший урожай. А это зависит от качества семян и удобрений. Поэтому он решил обратится к нам за кредитом. Деньги полученные в кредит дадут возможность купить качественные семена и удобрения. Таким образом он сможет получить качественный урожай.
texts.en:
Husan A. is a resident of the city of Yavan. He is married and has four children. He is 38 years old. He has worked in agriculture for his entire life. He plants onions and other types of vegetables. He has been in this type of business for his entire life. The business brings an income in the event that he gets a good harvest. This depends on the quality of the seeds and fertilizer. This is why he decided to turn to us for credit. Money that he receives from a loan will give him the opportunity to purchase quality seeds and fertilizer. This way he will be able to collect a high quality harvest.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and onion seeds

loans.name: Lorina

texts.en:
Lorina G. is a mother to three children and a 32-year-old wife to Forunato G.. She is a local of Culasi, Antique, Philippines, where the city is known as a center of commerce in the Northern part of the province. Her three children are all in elementary grades.

She started her business through loans from ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.). She started selling fried chicken with a rolling cart around the City Plaza. It caught the taste of the public and she was able to buy additional push carts.

Now her dream is to buy a motorcycle for easy and fast transportation of her goods. In addition, she plans to use this loan to buy more ingredients to make fried chicken. She is optimistic that the business she has started will grow. The proceeds from her business will be used to send her children to school until they reach college and find jobs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle, and to buy ingredients to make fried chicken.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is 40 years old, married, and the mother of two children. Currently all her children are in school.

Mary is a dealer and supplier of phone cards and phone chips. Her husband is a buyer and seller of gold. Mary is hardworking and very resourceful in the upbringing of the family.

Mary says that the sale of phone credits has become a very lucrative business in Ghana because almost every Ghanaian desires to possess a mobile phone and will definitely recharge their credit. She buys her supplies from agents at wholesale prices and sells to her customers at retail prices.

Mary requests a loan to enable her to procure an increased stock of mobile phone credits. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her savings and expand her shop, because she currently sells under an umbrella with a table stand. She would be grateful for your support. Mary belongs to a village bank called “1st Kings”.

loans.use: To procure an increased stock of mobile phone credits to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia M. is married with three children and has received an education through junior high school. Since 2004, she has worked as a trader in Elmina, selling clothes, various materials and shoes. While Cecilia works as a trader, her husband is employed as a miner.

She uses her income to help support her family and provide housekeeping money. Cecilia will use the loan to purchase additional clothes, shoes and materials to expand her business. With her newly gained profits, Cecilia plans to save in order to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase clothes, shoes and materials to expand her business

loans.name: Yawa Caroline

texts.fr: Cette femme est divorcée de son mari, elle vit avec ses 03 enfants  dans le quartier d’adidogomé, un quartier de la ville de Lomé. Pour subvenir aux charges de ses enfants, elle a commencé le commerce de céréales.  Les céréales sont très utilisés dans la cuisine togolaise pour préparer la nourriture comme la pâte. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays et exerce son commerce au marché local d’adidogomé. son stock de céréales est totalement épuisé, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et  sollicite donc un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 sacs de maïs, 10 sacs de mil, 07 sacs de riz, 02 sacs d’haricot et 01 sac de mil.
texts.en:
This woman is divorced from her husband and lives with her 3 children in the Adidogomé neighborhood, a district of the town of Lomé. To support her children, she began selling cereals. Cereals are much used in Togolese cuisine, to prepare traditional dishes. She buys her inventory out in the country and has her sales point in the local market of Adidogomé. Her stock of cereals is totally expended, so she would like to restock her business and is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 10 sacks of maize, 10 sacks of millet, 7 sacks of rice, and 2 sacks of dried beans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals for re-sale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Âgée de 33 ans, mariée  mère  de 4 enfants, Mariam S. a un statut de mariage polygame, mais vit seule avec  son mari et ses enfants  dans le quartier Sogomougou  de la préfecture de Koutiala ( Région de Sikasso ). 
Pour des raisons sociales elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Très tôt elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment  l’embouche qu’elle  a   appris auprès de sa maman. Elle exerce  cette activité depuis maintenant 8 ans  et elle lui est très rentable.  Elle peut vendre plus de 15 têtes dans le mois, pour les seuls clients étrangers. Sa notoriété ne cesse d’augmenter et elle est très sollicitée.    
Pour  la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle, et l’augmentation de  son chiffre d’affaire, Madame Mariam S. a décidé de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans.  Après avoir  8 prêts  solidaires  (prêt de groupe ) tous payés correctement sans difficulté, elle est à son 2 ème prêt individuel dont le précédent à été également bien remboursé. Madame Mariam envisage utiliser ce prêt pour l’achat  de 30 têtes  et des aliments bétail.  Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants  et dans la ville de Koutiala  et effectue sa vente dans le marché à bétail  de la ville de Koutiala à des clients Ivoiriens très généralement au comptant.   Madame compte sur un bénéfice de 150 000 FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des d’intérêts du prêt, contribuer aux dépenses  de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mariam S., age 33, is married and the mother of four. Her status is that she is in a polygamous marriage, though she lives alone with her husband and her children in the Sogomougou district of Koutiala prefecture (Sikasso region). For societal reasons, she did not attend school. She soon got interested in working to earn an income, notably in fattening livestock, a trade she learned from her mother. She has been in this business for eight years now, and it is very profitable. She can sell over fifteen heads of livestock each month for just foreign customers.

To do right by her customers and to increase her sales figures, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After eight solidarity loans (group loans), all correctly repaid without difficulty, she is on her second individual loan. The preceding loan was also repaid.

Ms. Mariam envisions using this loan to buy thirty heads of livestock and some feed. She supplies herself in and around the village of Koutiala and makes her sales generally in cash transactions at the livestock marketplace of Koutiala. Customers includes those from the Cote d'Ivoire.

She is counting on a profit of 150,000 francs CFA per month to be used to make loan interest payments, to help cover family expenses, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Adejoke

texts.fr: Adejoke O.  est une femme de 49 ans, marée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle est revendeuse de divers articles au bord da la route à Lomé. Pour permettre à son activité de répondre aux exigences de la clientèle, Adejoke espère avec ce deuxième crédit de FECECAV, construire une baraque et l’approvisionner afin de donner un cadre convivial à sa clientèle. Cette chance lui permettra d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaires et par conséquent mieux épargner pour la survie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Adejoke O., 49, is married and the mother of 4 children. She sells various items along the roadside in Lomé. In order to allow her business to respond to the demand of her clientele, Adejoke hopes, with this second loan from FECECAV, to build a little shed and outfit it, so as to have a more welcoming venue for her clientele. This good fortune will allow her to increase her turnover and thus be able to save better for the survival of her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: construct a shed and furnish it with goods

loans.name: Chu Thị Thơm Group

texts.en:
"T. Chu Thị (20213010046) is a 44-year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. T. is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is An Ninh 2 - 10 (10).

T. is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, T. owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling baked goods in the local community. T. has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,186,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA. T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1. Vũ Thị P. (20213010047) is a 35-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the agricultural sector raising livestock.

2. Vũ Thị L. (20213010048) is a 65-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business.

3. Dương Thị T. (20213010049) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,256,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.

4. Trần Thị Binh (20213010050) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.

5. Nguyễn Thị T. (20213010051) is a 38-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,256,000 VND loan to support her business in the agricultural sector raising livestock.

6. Lê Thị M. (20213010052) is a 35-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,704,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a tailoring business.

About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

*********************************************************
